<p><strong>The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)</strong> has made it clear that CO<sub>2</sub> removal (CDR) is a critical tool for achieving net zero by 2050<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ed744c83-5124-4058-8e9e-136df3c4d35c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ed744c83-5124-4058-8e9e-136df3c4d35c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Summary for policymakers,” in <em>Climate Change 2022: Mitigation of Climate Change</em>, IPCC, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> because they could enable businesses to neutralize residual carbon emissions once all emission reductions efforts have been exhausted. Thus, by 2050, CDR competency could be a core part of management responsibilities across all sectors.</p>
<p>This report provides an analysis of the market potential for CDR, the investment requirements, and market trends. It also identifies which actions are the most likely to lower barriers to scaling CDR and delineates potential advantages for first movers in different stakeholder groups.</p>
<h2>CDR’s role in reaching net zero</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This report is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/peter-mannion">Peter Mannion</a>, <a href="/our-people/emma-parry">Emma Parry</a>, <a href="/our-people/mark-patel">Mark Patel</a>, Erik Ringvold, and Jonathan Scott, representing views from McKinsey Sustainability and McKinsey’s Global Energy and Materials Practices.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Reducing emissions remains the primary, most effective, and preferred response to climate change. But decarbonization alone could prove insufficient to reduce the residual “hard to abate” emissions that may persist in the medium term. Once decarbonization options have been expended, CDR could play a vital role in neutralizing residual emissions; therefore, most scenarios aligned with the Paris Agreement project substantial CDR capacities. Estimates from the Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment’s <em>The state of carbon dioxide removal</em> report, for example, show that six to ten gigatons of CO<sub>2</sub> in annual CDR capacity would likely be needed by 2050 for most Paris-aligned net-zero pathways.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a20ee56-9698-4d3b-b618-d733bea6eb9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a20ee56-9698-4d3b-b618-d733bea6eb9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Climatic need estimates drawn from Stephen M. Smith et al., <em>The state of carbon dioxide removal</em>, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> This capacity could not be delivered quickly, however, so efforts would need to begin as soon as possible to ensure 2050 scenarios are achievable.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4d37b2e9-acbc-4c69-9cc8-a1fa41dedfa8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4d37b2e9-acbc-4c69-9cc8-a1fa41dedfa8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see Oliver Geden et al., “Near-term deployment of novel carbon removal to facilitate longer-term deployment,” <em>Joule</em>, November 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Some estimates require an additional 0.8 to 2.9 metric gigatons of CO<sub>2</sub> per year of removals capacity by 2030—three to ten times more than the volumes currently estimated to be onstream by that date.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e6284a90-2d27-47ec-a3cd-5178e3ba599e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e6284a90-2d27-47ec-a3cd-5178e3ba599e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Estimated volumes reflect direct air capture and storage (DACS) and bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) announced projects from public announcements. DACS includes an assumption of 30 metric megatons of CO2 (MtCO2) annual capacity phased in by 2030 from 1PointFive’s 75 Mt target, while BECCS includes all projects announced as net negative. Projected removals capacities from other CDR solutions were modeled using McKinsey’s Global Carbon Credits Model under a business-as-usual scenario.</span></span></span></a></span> Biotic feedback loops could also further accelerate the most severe effects of climate change, consequently increasing the speed at which CDR would need to be scaled.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Given CDR’s potential importance to achieving net-zero commitments, removals could become a routine consideration for businesses across sectors. For companies to claim they have reached net zero under the Science Based Targets initiative’s (SBTi’s) Corporate Net-Zero Standard, for example, after they have exhausted decarbonization actions, they must neutralize any residual emissions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="66bd255f-e54a-484c-8768-289636dbd497"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="66bd255f-e54a-484c-8768-289636dbd497" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>SBTi Corporate Net-Zero Standard</em>, SBTi, April 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> CDR can be especially pertinent for sectors with “hard-to-abate” emissions—those emissions that are technologically or economically prohibitive to reduce.</p>
<p>Closing the removals gap to achieve net zero would require a range of CDR solutions comprising both nature-based removals (NBR) and technology-based removals (TBR). NBR removes carbon by restoring, enhancing, or actively managing ecosystems. Because they tend to cost less per metric ton of CO<sub>2</sub> removed than emergent TBR, NBR could offer a more cost-effective path to increasing near-term CDR capacity. NBR could also play a role in removals over the long term, to ensure flexibility and balance in removals capacity. However, TBR generally delivers more “durable” removals by storing CO<sub>2</sub> permanently with minimal risk of rerelease into the atmosphere.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="46544efc-aca5-4774-a0f8-c1d895c17357"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="46544efc-aca5-4774-a0f8-c1d895c17357" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kaya Axelsson et al., “The meaning of net zero and how to get it right,” <em>Nature Climate Change</em>, 2022, Volume 15.</span></span></span></a></span> And durable solutions are generally preferable to ensure removals efforts remain effective in the long term, so increasing volumes of such solutions would be needed. Accelerating the scale-up of durable TBR would require near-term investment and innovation to reduce their relatively higher cost.</p>

Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--left__Izak1" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-0" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#26b3a8"><sup>Nature-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>1. Wetland and peatland restoration</h4>
<p>Restoring terrestrial wetlands and peatlands to absorb and store more CO<sub>2</sub></p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong><100</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong>15–40</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Increase biodiversity; improve water quality; reduce flood risks; eco-tourism</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Release of some greenhouse gases via restoration; uncertain permanence level; long-term monitoring and management</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--left__Izak1" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-1" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#26b3a8"><sup>Nature-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>2. Cropland, grassland, and agroforestry</h4>
<p>Improving cropland- and grassland-management practices to enhance CO<sub>2</sub> uptake from soils, and agroforestry to remove CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong><100</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong>10–30</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Increase biodiversity; enhance soil fertility and water retention; agricultural productivity</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Quantifying and monitoring carbon sequestration</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--left__Izak1" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-2" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#26b3a8"><sup>Nature-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>3. Reforestation and afforestation</h4>
<p>Tree planting in deforested or never-forested land to remove atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub></p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong><1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong>10–40</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Increase biodiversity and ecosystem resilience; eco-tourism</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Increased demand for land; release of sequestered CO<sub>2</sub><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dd55098a-2656-4051-bd6c-78acd7c3a17d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dd55098a-2656-4051-bd6c-78acd7c3a17d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The release of carbon back into the atmosphere (also known as reversal) can be caused by factors affecting tree growth, including pests and diseases, and weather events.</span></span></span></a></span>; risks of monoculture tree planting<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b53004a1-dc0d-4d2b-97c5-87de7a982dcc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b53004a1-dc0d-4d2b-97c5-87de7a982dcc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Compared with natural forests, monoculture tree planting can increase the vulnerability of forests to, for example, pests and diseases and natural disasters.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--left__Izak1" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-3" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#26b3a8"><sup>Nature-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>4. Blue carbon management</h4>
<p>Enhancing carbon uptake and storage of CO<sub>2</sub> in ocean and coastal ecosystems (eg, restoring mangroves, seagrasses, and tidal marshes; cultivating micro- and macroalgae)</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong><1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#26b3a8"><strong>25–250</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Improve marine ecosystems; enhance coastal resilience</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) for coastal and ocean ecosystems; regulatory uncertainty in international waters</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-4" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>5. Biochar and bio-oil</h4>
<p>Produced from biomass, biochar is spread to improve soil quality, and bio-oil is injected underground</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong><1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>90–220</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Enhanced soil fertility and water retention; uses for biomass residues from agricultural processes</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Increased demand for biomass feedstock and land; uncertain degree of soil permanence</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-5" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>6. Ocean alkalinity enhancement</h4>
<p>Adding alkaline substances to the ocean enhances its ability to absorb CO₂ from the atmosphere, accelerating the natural process</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>>1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>Uncertain</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Counter ocean acidification</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Effects on marine ecosystems from alkaline; MRV for ocean ecosystems; regulatory uncertainty in international waters</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-6" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>7. Enhanced weathering</h4>
<p>Rocks and minerals are broken down to increase surface area, speeding up processes that enable them to store carbon from the atmosphere</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>>1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>120–800</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Improve agricultural productivity</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Environmental and social effects; effects of trace metals in local ecosystem</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-7" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>8. Bioenergy with carbon capture and storage</h4>
<p>Sustainably sourced biomass to produce biofuels, electricity, heat, pulp; CO₂ emissions from these processes are captured and stored</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>>1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>60–270</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Additional revenue streams from generating coproducts (eg, electricity); retrofit to power plants</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Increased demand for biomass feedstock and land</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-8" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>9. Direct ocean capture</h4>
<p>Acid derived from ocean electrodialysis is used to chemically extract CO<sub>2</sub> from surface water; CO<sub>2</sub>  then placed in long-term storage</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>>1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>Uncertain</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Counter ocean acidification; use in coproducts (eg, sustainable aviation fuels)</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
Low technological readiness level at scale; MRV for open ocean ecosystems; high energy usage</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content__df3R_ OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--right__pq3hM OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-content--last-item__30i7f" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-9" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" class="OneColumnScrolly_mck-c-one-column-scrolly__text-item__mEsmr"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><span style="color:#36a3dd"><sup>Technology-based removals</sup></span>
<h4>10. Direct air capture and storage</h4>
<p>Air passes through solid or liquid chemical filter that binds to CO<sub>2</sub>, removing it from the air; concentrated CO<sub>2</sub> from filter is stored in underground geological formations</p>
<p><strong>Permanence,</strong> years<br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>>1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Cost 2023,</strong> $ per ton CO<sub>2</sub><br>
<span style="color:#36a3dd"><strong>500–1,000</strong></span></p>
<p><strong>Potential benefits</strong><br>
Use in coproducts (eg, sustainable aviation fuels); deploy across diverse geographies</p>
<p><strong>Potential challenges</strong><br>
High water and energy usage</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<h2>The CDR market: Trillion-dollar potential</h2>
<p>A CDR industry capable of delivering gigaton-scale removals at net-zero levels could be worth up to $1.2 trillion by 2050. This industry would require input and support from a range of players—including investors, suppliers, buyers, traders, and other intermediaries—with substantial potential value pools estimated for each (Exhibit 2). These are long-term business opportunities that would require early action to build removal volumes to scale by 2050.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge mdc-u-container-padding-primary mdc-u-container-margin-primary mck-c-module-wrapper mck-c-default-scrolly DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly--top-spaced__FZxVL" data-module-name="scrolly-container"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__scrolly-content__a5dCJ DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__scrolly-content--three-columns__Yxplk"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__scrolly-text-content__epRca mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__text-container__YYFld"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns text-content-9F9285A3AF4C485E8F723CE1C3D6C703" data-id="F6A7F48379B446E4A147DA653E329A4F" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-0" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>This report recognizes a strong degree of uncertainty in the future of the CO<sub>2</sub> removal (CDR) industry in terms of the volume of removals needed to address climatic needs, the mix of solutions that could be used to deliver these volumes, and the range of returns players across the value chain will be expected to deliver. Here we present the range of possible scenarios, with market sizes ranging from $300 billion to $1.2 trillion.</p>
<p>The data opposite, for example, shows the results of a scenario that requires lower rollout of CDR (due to faster decarbonization efforts, for example), with a higher share of nature-based removals (NBR) in the overall mix of removal solutions. Such a scenario could deliver a CDR industry of around $300 billion, with heavier weighting toward NBR. Note that NBR revenue shares remain comparatively lower than technology-based removals (TBR) because of the lower prices of NBR credits compared with TBR.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text__lFvee mck-c-default-scrolly__content-text--three-columns text-content-9F9285A3AF4C485E8F723CE1C3D6C703" data-id="3C61F8F19A8248ED876A5B1152AA7D56" data-react-scrollama-id="react-scrollama-1" entry="[object IntersectionObserverEntry]"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>In comparison, a scenario that requires higher rollout of CO<sub>2</sub> removal (CDR), combined with a higher use of technology-based removals (TBR) in the mix of removals, would create a significantly more expensive CDR industry worth up to $1.2 trillion. Because of higher-priced TBR options, market revenues would also be significantly more skewed toward TBR solutions in this scenario.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__scrolly-media-content__PFuk7" data-module-background="white" data-module-theme="light"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__container-sticky__vuA_2"><div class="media-container-9F9285A3AF4C485E8F723CE1C3D6C703 DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__media-container__IFEZ5"><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__media__7OJZA DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__media--visible__hDr4Z mck-u-animation-fade-in"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Suppliers will likely capture 70 to 80 percent of value in this industry, with traders likely capturing more value over time as the market matures. (1 of 2)" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/svgz-carboncapture-exscrolly3a.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="eager"></picture><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div><div class="DefaultScrolly_mck-c-default-scrolly__media__7OJZA mck-u-animation-fade-out"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Suppliers will likely capture 70 to 80 percent of value in this industry, with traders likely capturing more value over time as the market matures. (2 of 2)" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/svgz-carboncapture-exscrolly3b.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="eager"></picture><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Investment would be needed to support innovation to drive down costs and to support project development. Analysis in this report estimates the cumulative investment in CDR required to deliver net zero in 2050 at $6 trillion to $16 trillion (Exhibit 3). The investment need would depend on the volume of removals needed as well as the range of available CDR solutions. Estimates based on the current trajectory for investment, however, suggest investment could fall considerably short of these levels. In fact, the gap between estimated investment and what is estimated to be needed by 2030 to put CDR on track to meet 2050 targets is between $400 billion and $1.6 trillion.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/svgz-carboncapture-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Delivering CO2 removal capacities for net zero will likely require $6 trillion to $16 trillion of cumulative investment by 2050, far below expected levels." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/svgz-carboncapture-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Market trends: Reducing costs through CDR innovation</h2>
<p>The CDR market is currently trading at high prices and small volumes, particularly for emerging TBR. High prices for more durable CDR solutions are likely driven by small capacities and high costs of production. Innovation is key to fostering the higher volumes and lower prices needed to deliver CDR at scale. With continued demand, investment, and innovation, TBR costs are estimated to decline by at least 30 percent and up to 60 percent through 2035 and continue to drop through 2050, albeit more slowly as the industry scales (Exhibit 4). Costs for solutions that currently carry higher costs are estimated to decline fastest, though this scenario relies on the assumption that the required levels of investment and innovation can be achieved. NBR costs, on the other hand, may rise over time as land resources become constrained. NBR costs could rise by 20 to 60 percent through 2035, and 15 to 40 percent between 2035 and 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dc8adb16-2d36-484d-849d-00d9837e7dd2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dc8adb16-2d36-484d-849d-00d9837e7dd2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cost estimates derived from McKinsey TRAILS and Nature Analytics models for nature-based removals, and technology-specific cost models developed through literature review and McKinsey expert insights.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/carboncapture-ex4-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Technology-based removals costs are expected to decline over time, while costs for nature-based removals will likely increase." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/sustainability/our%20insights/carbon%20removals%20how%20to%20scale%20a%20new%20gigaton%20industry/carboncapture-ex4-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Lowering barriers to scaling CDR</h2>
<p>Scaling CDR to deliver net-zero removal volumes is a challenging endeavor, fraught with complexity and nuance. Indeed, the risks and challenges facing the industry have been documented at length,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="58c13234-6a3b-4273-83ba-52086e38a337"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="58c13234-6a3b-4273-83ba-52086e38a337" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Several sources have documented CDR market risks and challenges, including <em>Pathways to commercial liftoff: Carbon management</em>, US Department of Energy, April 2023; Freya Chay et al., <em>Barriers to scaling the long-duration carbon dioxide removal industry</em>, CarbonPlan, July 2022; <em>The case for negative emissions</em>, Coalition for Negative Emissions, June 2021; “Barriers to negative-emissions technologies,” <em>One Earth</em>, August 21, 2020, Volume 3, Number 2; Danny Cullenward et al., “Addressing critical challenges in carbon dioxide removal,” ClimateWorks Foundation, December 10, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and they include a need for stronger buyer incentives; improved transparency of standards, practices, and services; clear public-sector signals; innovation to unlock lower-cost solutions; and, of course, increased removals capacity. This report explores actions stakeholders across the CDR value chain could take to fulfill these needs.</p>
<p>Existing and developing policy measures and public funding have the potential to accelerate investment, along with enhanced project-level economics that reduce costs and improve future revenue streams. Governments, philanthropists, and nongovernmental organizations could work with the private sector to spur innovation—for example by addressing how CDR is incorporated into environmental, social, and governance (ESG) and carbon-accounting frameworks as well as how CDR could be integrated into cap-and-trade or carbon tax systems. Governments and philanthropists could also consider directly funding early-stage technology development or designing innovative financing arrangements that may help catalyze further private investment.</p>
<h2>Early-mover advantages in the CDR industry</h2>
<p>Although the challenges for scaling investment and innovation are not inconsiderable, tangible, long-term benefits are potentially available to those who engage in critical near-term efforts to scale the CDR industry. Indeed, the analysis in this report indicates that there may be strategic and competitive advantages available to early movers prepared to address these challenges together with other stakeholders.</p>
<h3>Investors</h3>
<p>Investors that engage early could gain valuable experience in spotting new opportunities and assessing their potential ahead of investors who wait for the market to grow before they engage. And CDR projects can have long lead times to start delivering removals—some TBR can take up to six to eight years to begin removing their first volumes of CO<sub>2</sub>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3f61145e-829c-4fb0-aee0-c4b4af76e6a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3f61145e-829c-4fb0-aee0-c4b4af76e6a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Angus Gillespie and Alex Townsend, “Scaling up the CCS market to deliver net-zero emissions,” Global CCS Institute, April 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Early alliances and support for growth enterprises could help investors reserve the right to play as the industry matures and scales. Early investors could also fortify their reputations as climate leaders by being at the forefront of creating an essential net-zero industry, potentially realizing $20 billion to $80 billion in CDR market revenues by 2050, according to the value pools analysis in this report.</p>
<h3>Suppliers</h3>
<p>Suppliers (CDR project developers that generate carbon credits based on capture and storage activities) could earn 73 to 82 percent of estimated CDR market revenues—$250 billion to $900 billion—by 2050. Because they carry out physical removal activities (such as carbon capture, transport, and storage) while other market players enable their efforts, suppliers could capture the largest share of industry revenues. When demand scales—for example, if CDR is recognized in carbon trading systems—suppliers will need to be able to respond rapidly to meet it. Because of what could be largely unrivaled access to technology, talent, and capital resources, established suppliers could have a significant advantage in expanding programs quickly and successfully. Early movers could be positioned to develop approaches to move down the learning curve sooner than those who engage later, thereby reducing early movers’ costs.</p>
<h3>Buyers</h3>
<p>Early buyers that sign future offtake agreements with suppliers could gain confidence that they will have a reliable future removals supply, even in the event of increased demand. If companies were required to purchase CDR to offset emissions—for example, following changes to regulations or guidelines on carbon offsets—then demand for CDR credits could rise sharply. Companies that made public net-zero commitments may require access to CDR urgently as they approach their stated deadlines. Early buyers may be more likely to secure a supply of reliable, high-quality CDR credits that could prove essential for hard-to-abate sectors to neutralize residual emissions and meet net-zero targets. In addition, a well-considered ESG strategy underpinned by CDR could support business aims such as talent recruitment and green premiums.</p>
<h3>Marketplaces and intermediaries</h3>
<p>As seen in other markets, as volumes grow for CDR, trading for removal volumes could coalesce around a small number of major marketplaces in a “winner takes all” dynamic. This dynamic would result from reduced intermediation costs and increased liquidity of the industry operating through a small number of marketplaces. Market intermediaries could earn 9 to 14 percent of estimated CDR market revenues—$40 billion to $140 billion—by 2050, according to the value pools analysis in this report. Marketplaces could aim to attract new and future buyers by moving early to establish a solid reputation for technical expertise, quality assurance, pricing knowledge, and the ability to diversify. Meanwhile, early-moving standards setters that develop high-integrity methodologies for the major CDR technologies could inform the core standard around which the voluntary carbon market for removals operates.</p>
<h3>Governments</h3>
<p>Governments that move early to support the CDR industry could shore up their domestic removal capacity to align their nationally determined contribution commitments with the Paris Agreement, satisfy other green commitments, and secure national supplies. CDR could be a global opportunity. A variety of CDR solutions means countries could utilize those solutions best suited to their particular geographies: for example, countries with access to low-cost renewable energy could enjoy cost advantages using energy-intensive CDR such as direct air capture. Likewise, countries with significant land-based natural assets could potentially benefit from expanded NBR; and coastal and island states could find emerging blue-carbon solutions afford them advantages. In addition, supporting CDR could provide governments with opportunities to promote skill development and job creation, thereby helping to facilitate a just transition to renewable energy sources.</p>
<p>Based on our analysis, CDR capabilities may become a core strategic concern for governments, investors, and businesses alike. This report offers analysis of the market potential for CDR, potential actions to scale CDR rapidly, and opportunities for near- and long-term advantages for early-moving CDR stakeholders. By reflecting on the analysis and data presented here, business leaders can gain a foundational understanding of CDR and how it may factor into their organizations’ net-zero strategies and overall goals. Bold actions taken today can scale CDR capacity to meet global net-zero requirements.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid industry","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"6f7fc87e-3dd7-4f02-b6c6-c623e1b0d94f","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Carbon removals: How to scale a new gigaton industry"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e removal (CDR) capacity is far from the gigaton scale needed to round out businesses\u0026rsquo; net-zero efforts by 2050. We explore a mature CDR market\u0026rsquo;s potential and possible first-mover advantages."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Explore the potential market and first-mover advantages to scaling carbon removals, which could become a trillion-dollar industry by 2050."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-12-04T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)\u003c/strong\u003e has made it clear that CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e removal (CDR) is a critical tool for achieving net zero by 2050[[footnote 1]] because they could enable businesses to neutralize residual carbon emissions once all emission reductions efforts have been exhausted. Thus, by 2050, CDR competency could be a core part of management responsibilities across all sectors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis report provides an analysis of the market potential for CDR, the investment requirements, and market trends. It also identifies which actions are the most likely to lower barriers to scaling CDR and delineates potential advantages for first movers in different stakeholder groups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCDR\u0026rsquo;s role in reaching net zero\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eReducing emissions remains the primary, most effective, and preferred response to climate change. But decarbonization alone could prove insufficient to reduce the residual \u0026ldquo;hard to abate\u0026rdquo; emissions that may persist in the medium term. Once decarbonization options have been expended, CDR could play a vital role in neutralizing residual emissions; therefore, most scenarios aligned with the Paris Agreement project substantial CDR capacities. Estimates from the Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003eThe state of carbon dioxide removal\u003c/em\u003e report, for example, show that six to ten gigatons of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e in annual CDR capacity would likely be needed by 2050 for most Paris-aligned net-zero pathways.[[footnote 2]] This capacity could not be delivered quickly, however, so efforts would need to begin as soon as possible to ensure 2050 scenarios are achievable.[[footnote 3]] Some estimates require an additional 0.8 to 2.9 metric gigatons of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e per year of removals capacity by 2030\u0026mdash;three to ten times more than the volumes currently estimated to be onstream by that date.[[footnote 4]] Biotic feedback loops could also further accelerate the most severe effects of climate change, consequently increasing the speed at which CDR would need to be scaled.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eGiven CDR\u0026rsquo;s potential importance to achieving net-zero commitments, removals could become a routine consideration for businesses across sectors. For companies to claim they have reached net zero under the Science Based Targets initiative\u0026rsquo;s (SBTi\u0026rsquo;s) Corporate Net-Zero Standard, for example, after they have exhausted decarbonization actions, they must neutralize any residual emissions.[[footnote 5]] CDR can be especially pertinent for sectors with \u0026ldquo;hard-to-abate\u0026rdquo; emissions\u0026mdash;those emissions that are technologically or economically prohibitive to reduce.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClosing the removals gap to achieve net zero would require a range of CDR solutions comprising both nature-based removals (NBR) and technology-based removals (TBR). NBR removes carbon by restoring, enhancing, or actively managing ecosystems. Because they tend to cost less per metric ton of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e removed than emergent TBR, NBR could offer a more cost-effective path to increasing near-term CDR capacity. NBR could also play a role in removals over the long term, to ensure flexibility and balance in removals capacity. However, TBR generally delivers more \u0026ldquo;durable\u0026rdquo; removals by storing CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e permanently with minimal risk of rerelease into the atmosphere.[[footnote 6]] And durable solutions are generally preferable to ensure removals efforts remain effective in the long term, so increasing volumes of such solutions would be needed. Accelerating the scale-up of durable TBR would require near-term investment and innovation to reduce their relatively higher cost.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up sust]]\n\u003ch3\u003eUnderstanding ten CDR solutions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo further explore the range of methods to capture and store CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e, jump to individual CDR solutions for both nature-based and technology-based removals below (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Scrolly 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe CDR market: Trillion-dollar potential\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA CDR industry capable of delivering gigaton-scale removals at net-zero levels could be worth up to $1.2 trillion by 2050. This industry would require input and support from a range of players\u0026mdash;including investors, suppliers, buyers, traders, and other intermediaries\u0026mdash;with substantial potential value pools estimated for each (Exhibit 2). These are long-term business opportunities that would require early action to build removal volumes to scale by 2050.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Scrolly 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eInvestment would be needed to support innovation to drive down costs and to support project development. Analysis in this report estimates the cumulative investment in CDR required to deliver net zero in 2050 at $6 trillion to $16 trillion (Exhibit 3). The investment need would depend on the volume of removals needed as well as the range of available CDR solutions. Estimates based on the current trajectory for investment, however, suggest investment could fall considerably short of these levels. In fact, the gap between estimated investment and what is estimated to be needed by 2030 to put CDR on track to meet 2050 targets is between $400 billion and $1.6 trillion.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMarket trends: Reducing costs through CDR innovation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe CDR market is currently trading at high prices and small volumes, particularly for emerging TBR. High prices for more durable CDR solutions are likely driven by small capacities and high costs of production. Innovation is key to fostering the higher volumes and lower prices needed to deliver CDR at scale. With continued demand, investment, and innovation, TBR costs are estimated to decline by at least 30 percent and up to 60 percent through 2035 and continue to drop through 2050, albeit more slowly as the industry scales (Exhibit 4). Costs for solutions that currently carry higher costs are estimated to decline fastest, though this scenario relies on the assumption that the required levels of investment and innovation can be achieved. NBR costs, on the other hand, may rise over time as land resources become constrained. NBR costs could rise by 20 to 60 percent through 2035, and 15 to 40 percent between 2035 and 2050.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003eLowering barriers to scaling CDR\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eScaling CDR to deliver net-zero removal volumes is a challenging endeavor, fraught with complexity and nuance. Indeed, the risks and challenges facing the industry have been documented at length,[[footnote 8]] and they include a need for stronger buyer incentives; improved transparency of standards, practices, and services; clear public-sector signals; innovation to unlock lower-cost solutions; and, of course, increased removals capacity. This report explores actions stakeholders across the CDR value chain could take to fulfill these needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExisting and developing policy measures and public funding have the potential to accelerate investment, along with enhanced project-level economics that reduce costs and improve future revenue streams. Governments, philanthropists, and nongovernmental organizations could work with the private sector to spur innovation\u0026mdash;for example by addressing how CDR is incorporated into environmental, social, and governance (ESG) and carbon-accounting frameworks as well as how CDR could be integrated into cap-and-trade or carbon tax systems. Governments and philanthropists could also consider directly funding early-stage technology development or designing innovative financing arrangements that may help catalyze further private investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEarly-mover advantages in the CDR industry\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the challenges for scaling investment and innovation are not inconsiderable, tangible, long-term benefits are potentially available to those who engage in critical near-term efforts to scale the CDR industry. Indeed, the analysis in this report indicates that there may be strategic and competitive advantages available to early movers prepared to address these challenges together with other stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInvestors\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvestors that engage early could gain valuable experience in spotting new opportunities and assessing their potential ahead of investors who wait for the market to grow before they engage. And CDR projects can have long lead times to start delivering removals\u0026mdash;some TBR can take up to six to eight years to begin removing their first volumes of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e.[[footnote 9]] Early alliances and support for growth enterprises could help investors reserve the right to play as the industry matures and scales. Early investors could also fortify their reputations as climate leaders by being at the forefront of creating an essential net-zero industry, potentially realizing $20 billion to $80 billion in CDR market revenues by 2050, according to the value pools analysis in this report.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSuppliers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuppliers (CDR project developers that generate carbon credits based on capture and storage activities) could earn 73 to 82 percent of estimated CDR market revenues\u0026mdash;$250 billion to $900 billion\u0026mdash;by 2050. Because they carry out physical removal activities (such as carbon capture, transport, and storage) while other market players enable their efforts, suppliers could capture the largest share of industry revenues. When demand scales\u0026mdash;for example, if CDR is recognized in carbon trading systems\u0026mdash;suppliers will need to be able to respond rapidly to meet it. Because of what could be largely unrivaled access to technology, talent, and capital resources, established suppliers could have a significant advantage in expanding programs quickly and successfully. Early movers could be positioned to develop approaches to move down the learning curve sooner than those who engage later, thereby reducing early movers\u0026rsquo; costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuyers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarly buyers that sign future offtake agreements with suppliers could gain confidence that they will have a reliable future removals supply, even in the event of increased demand. If companies were required to purchase CDR to offset emissions\u0026mdash;for example, following changes to regulations or guidelines on carbon offsets\u0026mdash;then demand for CDR credits could rise sharply. Companies that made public net-zero commitments may require access to CDR urgently as they approach their stated deadlines. Early buyers may be more likely to secure a supply of reliable, high-quality CDR credits that could prove essential for hard-to-abate sectors to neutralize residual emissions and meet net-zero targets. In addition, a well-considered ESG strategy underpinned by CDR could support business aims such as talent recruitment and green premiums.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMarketplaces and intermediaries\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs seen in other markets, as volumes grow for CDR, trading for removal volumes could coalesce around a small number of major marketplaces in a \u0026ldquo;winner takes all\u0026rdquo; dynamic. This dynamic would result from reduced intermediation costs and increased liquidity of the industry operating through a small number of marketplaces. Market intermediaries could earn 9 to 14 percent of estimated CDR market revenues\u0026mdash;$40 billion to $140 billion\u0026mdash;by 2050, according to the value pools analysis in this report. Marketplaces could aim to attract new and future buyers by moving early to establish a solid reputation for technical expertise, quality assurance, pricing knowledge, and the ability to diversify. Meanwhile, early-moving standards setters that develop high-integrity methodologies for the major CDR technologies could inform the core standard around which the voluntary carbon market for removals operates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGovernments\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments that move early to support the CDR industry could shore up their domestic removal capacity to align their nationally determined contribution commitments with the Paris Agreement, satisfy other green commitments, and secure national supplies. CDR could be a global opportunity. A variety of CDR solutions means countries could utilize those solutions best suited to their particular geographies: for example, countries with access to low-cost renewable energy could enjoy cost advantages using energy-intensive CDR such as direct air capture. Likewise, countries with significant land-based natural assets could potentially benefit from expanded NBR; and coastal and island states could find emerging blue-carbon solutions afford them advantages. In addition, supporting CDR could provide governments with opportunities to promote skill development and job creation, thereby helping to facilitate a just transition to renewable energy sources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on our analysis, CDR capabilities may become a core strategic concern for governments, investors, and businesses alike. This report offers analysis of the market potential for CDR, potential actions to scale CDR rapidly, and opportunities for near- and long-term advantages for early-moving CDR stakeholders. By reflecting on the analysis and data presented here, business leaders can gain a foundational understanding of CDR and how it may factor into their organizations\u0026rsquo; net-zero strategies and overall goals. Bold actions taken today can scale CDR capacity to meet global net-zero requirements.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Report"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":true},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-12-04T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Summary for policymakers,\u0026rdquo; in \u003cem\u003eClimate Change 2022: Mitigation of Climate Change\u003c/em\u003e, IPCC, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eClimatic need estimates drawn from Stephen M. CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e removal (CDR) industry in terms of the volume of removals needed to address climatic needs, the mix of solutions that could be used to deliver these volumes, and the range of returns players across the value chain will be expected to deliver. Here we present the range of possible scenarios, with market sizes ranging from $300 billion to $1.2 trillion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe data opposite, for example, shows the results of a scenario that requires lower rollout of CDR (due to faster decarbonization efforts, for example), with a higher share of nature-based removals (NBR) in the overall mix of removal solutions. Such a scenario could deliver a CDR industry of around $300 billion, with heavier weighting toward NBR. Note that NBR revenue shares remain comparatively lower than technology-based removals (TBR) because of the lower prices of NBR credits compared with TBR.\u003c/p\u003e"},"textComponentPlacement":{"targetItem":null},"textComponentBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/sustainability/our insights/carbon removals how to scale a new gigaton industry/svgz-carboncapture-exscrolly3a.svgz","alt":"Suppliers will likely capture 70 to 80 percent of value in this industry, with traders likely capturing more value over time as the market matures.
